stem: The nurse is monitoring end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2) in the Post-Anesthesia Care Unit (PACU). Match each clinical condition with its expected effect on the capnography waveform.

rows.text: Hyperventilation due to pain or anxiety.
Sudden loss of the waveform (EtCO2 decreases to zero).

rationale.correct: Capnography provides instant feedback on ventilation. (r1) Opioids slow breathing, letting CO2 build up (High EtCO2). (r2) Rapid breathing 'blows off' CO2 (Low EtCO2). (r3) A flatline indicates total loss of ventilation (Apnea/Dislodgement). (r4) Slowing ventilation or increased CO2 production (like malignant hyperthermia) causes a rising baseline.
rationale.incorrect: Low EtCO2 does not mean 'good' breathing; it can mean hyperventilation or poor cardiac output (pulmonary embolism).
clinicalPearls: EtCO2 is often the first indicator of respiratory depression, appearing before oxygen saturation (SpO2) drops.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that a Pulmonary Embolism causes a sudden DROP in EtCO2 (because CO2 can't get to the lungs to be exhaled) despite the patient breathing fast. This is a common NGN advanced monitoring trap.

mnemonic.title: H-i-v-s-L-o
mnemonic.expansion: High EtCO2 = Slow breathing. Low EtCO2 = Fast breathing (or no PERFUSION).

reviewUnits.heading: End-Tidal CO2 Monitoring
reviewUnits.body: Nurses use capnography for patients on PCA pumps, during sedation, and to verify endotracheal tube placement. Normal range is 35-45 mmHg.
